segments.key_quote: In this way the Pandavas were going on accumulating pious credits. On the other hand Duryodhana was merely enjoying all the royal opulence and he was not engaged in conducting any fire sacrifice or yajnas.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts the Pandavas' austere life in exile, focused on spiritual practices, with Duryodhana's opulent lifestyle and envy, setting the stage for Duryodhana's plan to show off his wealth.
segments.transcript: Welcome to today's episode of the Mahabharata. In the last episode we have seen how the Pandavas, being in the forest exile, were engaged in executing various kinds of austerity. They were living in the forest, sometimes shuttling between Dwaitavana and Kamyakavana. They were living in simple thatched cottages with mud flooring. They were wearing dresses made out of tree bark. And they were constantly engaged in conducting yajna, sacrifices to please Lord Vishnu. And having obtained from the sun god, Suryadeva, a magical pot which could produce unlimited amount of food for feeding the guests. With that Draupadi would everyday cook and feed large number of saintly people who would come and attend the yajnas conducted by Yudhishthir Maharaj. In this way the Pandavas were going on accumulating pious credits. On the other hand Duryodhana was merely enjoying all the royal opulence and he was not engaged in conducting any fire sacrifice or yajnas. He was simply enjoying the power and opulence of the royal household and thus he was using up all his previous pious credits. Two contrasting things we were able to see. And when the Pandavas entered the twelfth year of their forest exile, Duryodhana based on the instigation by Karna decided to go to Dwaitavana to show off his opulence. How much wealth he had acquired and with all the women folk, with all the resources, with some small army with him. He wanted to go there and show off to the Pandavas because look out how I am enjoying life and how you people are suffering. During these twelve years, Duryodhana had spent time not only in increasing the strength of his army but also in striking of alliances with various friendly kings and he was like this building up his army power. So that he knew later when the Pandavas would come to seek their kingdom back, he could very easily rebuff.

segments.key_quote: Now when Duryodhana heard this proposal from Karna that it is good to go and show up to the Pandavas and rub salt on their wounds, it appealed very much to Duryodhana because we all have seen how Duryodhana is very envious by nature and he liked to insult the Pandavas although there was no fault on their side.
segments.summary: Duryodhana, motivated by envy and instigated by Karna, seeks permission from Dhritarashtra to visit Dwaitavana under the guise of inspecting cows, concealing his true intention to humiliate the Pandavas.
segments.transcript: Now when Duryodhana heard this proposal from Karna that it is good to go and show up to the Pandavas and rub salt on their wounds, it appealed very much to Duryodhana because we all have seen how Duryodhana is very envious by nature and he liked to insult the Pandavas although there was no fault on their side. Now for Duryodhana to go to Dwaitavana, an excuse was needed. So he went to his father Dhritarasva and he told him that the time has come to count, to take count of all the cows. And inspect them for their health and well-being whether the caretakers are taking good care of them or not. So I am planning to go with a small retinue, with a small portion, segment of my army I want to take and all the women folk and my wife and all those people I want to take them and go to the place where the cows are currently which happens to be Dwaitavana. Dhritarasva when he heard this, immediately he said, why are you going to Dwaitavana? The Pandavas are already there, if you go there and by chance both of you come to meet each other, I don't want another fight between the two of you. So why you have to go? Send some important minister or general or somebody like that, why do you have to personally go? But then Duryodhana was adamant, he wanted to go himself although he could not openly express it to Dhritarasva. Then Shakuni also supported Duryodhana and told Dhritarasva, why we will go to Dwaitavana? Why? All the Pandavas, they are already in forest exile, they are practically nobody now, why will we go to them? Forget it, we are going for our other purpose, we will keep away from them. So Dhritarasva finally relented and he said, okay, if you want to go, we are very insistent you go but don't trouble the Pandavas.

segments.key_quote: Duryodhana with his retinue, he reached Vaithavana and which is said to be modern day Dev Vand in Uttar Pradesh and having reached there, he inspected all the cows, took count of them, asked about the health, he looked up the health records of all the cows and having considered all these things, having finished all his duties.
segments.summary: Duryodhana travels to Dwaitavana with his army and advisors, completing the pretense of inspecting the cows, and then sends scouts to find a suitable location to set up camp near the Pandavas to flaunt his opulence.
segments.transcript: Now having got Dhritarasva's permission, Duryodhana took off with his small army, few horses, a few foot soldiers and some chariots like that, few means a few thousand, not that small also. And then Duryodhana was accompanied by Karna, Shakuni and Dushasana and his other brothers who all wanted to see the fun, how the Pandavas are going to be, you know, they are going to be insulted and they are going to be humiliated, that was the, they wanted to join in the fun. So they all went. Duryodhana with his retinue, he reached Vaithavana and which is said to be modern day Dev Vand in Uttar Pradesh and having reached there, he inspected all the cows, took count of them, asked about the health, he looked up the health records of all the cows and having considered all these things, having finished all his duties. Then he went. He sent some people to figure out in the Vaithavana where the Pandavas are and he told his people go and set up camp close to where they are in such a way that they can see us and we will have some revelry and some celebration and we will have some dancing, music and all those kind of things and that will rub the Pandavas this one ego, that was Duryodhana's this one. So the few people, some few soldiers from his army, they went seeking out a place where they could set camp and also in such a way that it would be visible for the Pandavas. The Pandavas at that moment, Yudhishthira Maharaj was engaged in a fire sacrifice, a yajna was going on and he was along with a few other Rishis and Sages and Ramanas who were conducting the fire sacrifice, he was involved in that. The Pandavas of course were totally unaware of Duryodhana's impending visit. So this small group of army was going forward, they came across the place near a lake on the bank of the lake where the Pandavas were being seated.

segments.key_quote: Some Gandharvas had come there, to that forest...Hindradeva...did not like this activity from this act of Duryodhana's where he wanted to humiliate the Pandavas...Gandharvas and told them, see like this Duryodhana is going to Dwaitavana with an evil intention, you go and take care of him.
segments.summary: Gandharvas, sent by Indra due to Duryodhana's malicious intentions, arrive in Dwaitavana and prevent Duryodhana's forces from setting up camp, leading to an impending conflict.

segments.key_quote: Now, a fierce battle started with between the small army of Duryodhana along with Karna, Shakuni, Dushasana and others and on the other side, a small group of the Gandharvas...Finally, what happened? Shakuni ran away from the battlefield when he saw that his life was in danger.
segments.summary: A battle ensues between Duryodhana's army and the Gandharvas, resulting in the Kauravas' defeat, the cowardly retreat of Karna, Shakuni, and Dushasana, and Duryodhana's capture.
segments.transcript: with their weapons. Now, a fierce battle started with between the small army of Duryodhana along with Karna, Shakuni, Dushasana and others and on the other side, a small group of the Gandharvas. Now, although Karna was a powerful archer, Duryodhana himself was a great warrior. Despite all this, the Gandharvas being celestial beings, gradually they drove back Duryodhana's army. Finally, what happened? Shakuni ran away from the battlefield when he saw that his life was in danger. So also, when Karna saw that his arrows were failing and he too was in a very precarious condition, he along with Dushasana and the other brothers of Duryodhana, they all ran away from the battlefield. Actually, a Kshatriya is never supposed to show his back in a battle. A Kshatriya is supposed to fight till the death. But this cowardly act from the side of Karna and Dushasana and others was not surprising because they were used to very boastful and ostentatious claims, although they did not have the real powers like the Pandavas. That is why they were always envious of the Pandavas because the Pandavas actually, even though they were very humble and very nice people, the Kauravas, Karna and Duryodhana and others knew that the Pandavas were, always far more powerful than them and far more opulent than them. That was why Duryodhana and Karna and others were always envious of the Pandavas. Be that as it may, the whole Kaurava army was defeated, it was routed, practically almost all their army was destroyed, and Karna, Dushasana and others, Shakuni and others, ran away from the battlefield in a cowardly manner. Now, Duryodhana stood fighting there and finally, Duryodhana was captured by the Dandarvas. So, whatever little bit of Duryodhana's army was left, they ran away.

segments.key_quote: So they consulted amongst themselves and they thought it wise to approach the Pandavas and seek their help because they were close at hand...The moment Pandavas heard that Duryodhana had come there and he had been captured by the Gandharvas, they immediately understood what was the background of this whole incident.
segments.summary: Duryodhana's remaining soldiers seek help from the Pandavas, who, despite knowing Duryodhana's intentions, are bound by their Kshatriya dharma to offer protection.
segments.transcript: But still, they were lamenting that our master has been captured, now what to do? So they consulted amongst themselves and they thought it wise to approach the Pandavas and seek their help because they were close at hand to go back to Hastinapura and to call Bhishma Dev and bring him back and Dronacharya and others was practically next to impossible. Something had to be done right there, right then. So this remaining small group of people, the soldiers went and approached Yudhishthir Maharaj who was in the midst of performing the Ejna and they narrated the whole thing before him. Of course, this group of soldiers, they did not know Duryodhana's evil intention, his malified intention in coming there to actually humiliate the Pandavas. They were thinking he came here to count the cows and all those kind of things and after finishing all that, he wanted to just sit, camp there, relax a little bit and go back to Hastinapura. That was their understanding. The moment Pandavas heard that Duryodhana had come there and he had been captured by the Gandharvas, they immediately understood what was the background of this whole incident. Bhima said, We would have had to undergo a great effort and endeavor with a great assembly of horses and elephants and chariots and soldiers, in order to get it.
